newsitem.title: UK: INSIGHT - RESISTANCE AT $330 STILL PESTERING GOLD.
newsitem.headline: INSIGHT - RESISTANCE AT $330 STILL PESTERING GOLD.

text.p: SPOT NY CLOSE * SUPPORT * RESIST * RSI14 * MA10 * MA30
Gold is still capped by resistance at $330 despite gyrations in stock and currency markets. But it may yet benefit from volatility in other markets, dealers said.
Silver made upside progress on Wednesday but prices need to decisively clear the $4.50 level before moving higher.
GOLD - The market's latest attempt to push through the $330 level was spurned on Wednesday as the market is still bearish in the longer term and meeting steady selling pressure, dealers said.
Spot gold was bid as high as $329.20 on Wednesday as it tracked volatile action in U.S. stocks and bonds, but then it was sold down again.
"Any time gold goes up two or three dollars, nervous producers sell into the market. Gold is still in a $326-$329 price range," a senior European dealer said.
"But both gold and silver could benefit from further volatility on the stock market," he added.
Spot gold was quoted at $326.80/$327.20 at 0745 GMT, compared to Wendesday's London close of $327.60/$328.10 and New York finish of $326.90/$327.40.
SILVER - Prices leapt higher on Wednesday, at one point hitting a high of $4.56, but to continue making upside progress silver will have to establish a foothold above $4.50, dealers said.
"It traded above $4.50 yesterday but I don't see it clearly established above there," one said.
Spot silver was last indicated at $4.48/$4.50, off two cents from previous London close.
PLATINUM - A lack of fresh news from producer Russia and importer Japan has left the platinum group metals adrift for now although the market is still very tight.
"The PGMs...continue to consolidate after the sell-offs following the contract highs earlier this month," brokers Rudolf Wolff said in a commentary.
Platinum should find initial support at $430, then at $425 and $420, while resistance is at $440, analysts said.
Spot platinum was last indicated at $432.00/$435.00, down $1.00 from Wednesday's London close.
--Lida Poletz, London newsroom +44 171 542 2936
